column2: Special Update - One Kiva Lender's Journey to Armenia
column3:
The letter and story below was written for you by the CEO of SEF International, one of Kiva's Field Partners in Armenia. The organization truly appreciates your support and hopes you will continue lending to Armenian borrowers on Kiva.

Dear Lender,

Thank you for your trust and support. Your loans have played a significant role in the lives of borrowers and their families, and have made a positive change in their lives.

I want to tell you a story about one Kiva lender's visit to his borrowers. It was a great experience for the borrowers, the lender and the SEF team. The lender witnessed the impact his investment had made, the borrowers felt the direct support of the Kiva community, and we at SEF were proud to be a part of their connection.

I want to share this eye-opening experience with you and invite you to Armenia to visit your borrowers. We here at SEF stand ready to take care of the logistics for you and help you enjoy your visit.

Thank you again for your support. You help improve lives.

Sincerely,

Garegin Gavorgyan

CEO, SEF International

SMALL ACTIONS MAKE A BIG DIFFERENCE

Meet Sebastia from Sydney Australia. He joined Kiva in 2011, and has since become one of the site's most active lenders. He's made 329 loans, 190 of which went to SEF borrowers (as of this month).

In August 2012, Sebastia came to Armenia for the first time. He is ethnic Armenian and was excited to see the land of his ancestors, to meet people, and to get acquainted with their lives. Sebastia came to see how the Kiva platform works in the field and how loans have affected the lives of borrowers.

Sebastia and Anahit from SEF visited two Kiva borrowers. The first borrower, Ruben, had applied for a loan to purchase carrot seeds and fertilizer for his grape orchard. Ruben grows a large variety of grape types and gladly offered to have Sebastia and Anahit taste all of them as he talked about their different attributes, tastes and cultivation practices.

Ruben shared that he would not have had as large a harvest without organic fertilizer, especially since several diseases have become much more common in the region, decreasing the land's productivity. The fertilizer has also ensured the high quality of his grapes. After the harvest, Ruben sells his grapes to a local winery.

Ruben has also started to cultivate carrots in late autumn, which is not the most favorable time for this plant. Last year's carrot harvest was not as good as the grape harvest, but Ruben hasn't lost hope and is determined to grow carrots again this year.

Sebastia and Anahit also visited Kiva borrower Susanna, who is also in agriculture.She applied for a loan to purchase two calves, stakes for her grape orchard, plant medicine and organic fertilizer. Susanna was very excited about the calves she has purchased. They'll give her the opportunity to breed cattle and produce more milk.

Susanna grows different vegetables in her orchard: peppers, eggplants, and tomatos. The seeds and organic fertilizer she purchased have played an important role in maintaining a healthy harvest.

While it was a little early for harvesting tomatos during the visit, Susanna found a few red ones so Sebastia and Anahit could have a taste.

Sebastia was thrilled to see, touch and taste the tangible results of the loans he made. It was very important for him to talk to the borrowers, learn about the challenges they face, and see how he has helped them. He said he was very excited to support so many Armenian entrepreneurs, and continue collaborating with SEF by making more loans.

We here at SEF value these experiences and welcome you to visit your borrowers, share your stories and support us in making sure that the poor in Armenia have access to the financial services they need.

Belsi tiene 48 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive con sus hijos en la aldea Ceguaca de Santa Bárbara. Y comenta que le fue muy bien, pago su préstamo sin problemas y sus ingresos aumentaron. El local del negocio está mejor acondicionado y es más eficiente ahora. Esta muy agradecido por el préstamo ya que ayuda al crecimiento. Su sueño es apoyar a su hija con los estudios y por eso está ahorrando.

Le ayudo a incrementar sus ventas y sus ingresos, además cumplió con los pedidos que tenía pendientes de sus clientes. Su sueño es tener un local donde establecer el negocio en un lugar céntrico de la ciudad.

El financiamiento solicitado fue invertido en el fortalecimiento del negocio compra de ganado pecuario y porcino (vacas y cerdos) para la crianza. También quiere comenzar la construcción de una casa para poder independizarme, ya que actualmente esta viviendo con su padres.

column2: Burenjargal is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Burenjargal has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Burenjargal is 26 years old, married, and has two children who attend school. She lives in a small house with her family in the outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her spouse is self-employed. Burenjargal has worked at a few popular beauty salons in the city for three years. She operates the same salon mentioned in her previous loan and supports her family with it. Head massages, facial treatments, and eyebrow tattoos are the main services offered at her salon. Burenjargal is requesting a loan for 1,200,000 MNT which she will use to purchase construction materials to renovate her house's fence which has become old and unsafe. "If I will finish this renovating work, I will very cozy and safe," she said. You can see Burenjargal's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481056?_te=rlnol.

column2: John is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that John has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: John is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. John will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. His hopes and dreams are to venture into pig-rearing, which will improve the living standard of his family. You can see John's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481058?_te=rlnol.

column2: James\t\t\t is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that James has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: James is 24 years old. He is single but he takes care of one 3-year-old child of his relative who passed away. He sells different merchandise and has been in the business for the past three years. He wants the loan to buy more sugar, maize and salt for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest in the business. You can see James 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481047?_te=rlnol.

Teresa would like to extend her sincerest thanks to ASKI and KIVA lenders for the financial assistance they had provide to make improvement in her food production business. She is now enjoying the increased in income observed in her daily selling. Teresa hopes for the continuous development of her vending activity thus she could get greater profits that will help satisfy her customers and family everyday living.

The amount availed served as added capital in buying for hog feed and vaccine for the maintenance of her hog fattening and breeding business. Now, Lualhati decided to work abroad and she is waiting for schedules when to flight across the country that is why she did not get loan again after her previous loan full payment.

Delia had successfully repaid back the loan borrowed from ASKI and KIVA lenders which helped increased her store inventories. She hopes to keep her retail store productive and competitive so she could have a stable source of income which will enable her to save amounts for future security. She wanted to thank ASKI and KIVA lenders for lending her the loan requested. For the third time, Delia has availed again another loan amount.

However, as to Norwina, she will do her best to give full update on the loan to get again next time and further invest it for further improvement of her food selling business.

column2: Roman is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Roman has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Roman works in the auto market selling auto parts for cars and motorcycles. He has a well-located trading point where there are always passers-by and clients who have a long-running relationship with Roman. As an entrepreneur, Roman is orderly, always punctual and hard-working. He needs this loan to purchase auto parts for Russian and domestic automobiles, bulbs, lights, radiators and xenon. You can see Roman's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/483254?_te=rlnol.

column2: Kharitina is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Kharitina has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Kharitina works in a large local market where she sells live flowers and houseplants. Her trading point, the flower pavilion, is open 24 hours a day. The pavilion is in a very good, high-traffic location. Kharitina is diligent, always at work, honest and pleasant. She needs this loan to purchase her next batch of live flowers in Kharkiv. You can see Kharitina's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/483249?_te=rlnol.

column2: Zoya is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Zoya has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Zoya works in one of the biggest flea markets, as well as in a local shopping mall. She has three trading points and she sells women's clothing: blazers, jackets, skirts and pants. Her trading points are very well-positioned in high-traffic areas of the market. Zoya herself is a very polite woman who is organized and always in her trading stall. She needs this loan to make a routine trip to Kharkiv to increase her range of goods and to buy women's jackets and blazers for fall. You can see Zoya's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/483243?_te=rlnol.

column2: Irina is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Irina has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Irina sells men’s and women’s clothing at a big local shopping center. She also has a sales outlet at the central market of her town. Irina needs financial support in order to stock up on fall merchandise—women’s and men’s clothing. She plans to buy women’s cardigans, sweaters, men’s jeans, sports pants and also wind jackets. You can see Irina's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/483240?_te=rlnol.

column2: Ana Lidia Del Carmen is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Ana Lidia Del Carmen has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Ana Lidia, 57, lives with her life companion, their children and her mother in her own house. She has a restaurant wherein she prepares a variety of dishes: soups, meats, rice, salads, pupusas [filled, grilled corncakes] and beverages, among others. She’s been in business for several years and has wide experience cooking which allows her to earn the best profits. She sells from home which is located in a very busy area. She’s acquired a large number of regular customers who prefer her because her dishes are the most delicious and they are made with quality raw materials under hygienic conditions. Prices are affordable and, above all, service is excellent. Ana is an enterprising woman who is dedicated to her work; she’s always on the lookout for alternatives that will give her the opportunity of finding the best path to success and she will not rest until she reaches it. She wants to make a new investment to increase production but needs capital to back her up which is why she’s asking INTEGRAL for a loan to buy basic grains, meat, dairy products, vegetables, etc. as well as to repair the pupusa grill. Ana has good payment references and she accepts the responsibility of the debt while at the same time has faith that she will provide economic security for her home. You can see Ana Lidia Del Carmen's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481945?_te=rlnol.

column2: Susan  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Susan has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Susan is applying for her second business loan from KADET LTD to finance her business. She plans to use the loan to buy more cows for slaughter to be able to supply more meat to her customers. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her child and expand her business further. She hopes to have a bigger, more profitable business. You can see Susan 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480808?_te=rlnol.

column2: Ana is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Ana has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: The group is made up of four successful entrepreneurs, including Anna del Socorro. On weekends, she sells nacatamales (Nicaraguan tamales) and a variety of food from her home. She has been engaged in this business for 15 years. She started it on her own, together with her children, producing food on a small scale. She wants to use the loan to buy other products, in order to diversify her business by purchasing plastic products such as plastic washtubs, pails, plates, etc. Maria de la Luz sells enchiladas, pinolillo (cornmeal and cocoa beverage), and rice pudding. Ivania sells food on weekends from her home. Dora Antonia has a small general store. You can see Ana's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481912?_te=rlnol.

column2: Rosa María  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Rosa María has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Rosa María lives with her life companion, Antonio, her children and her mother in her own house. She works selling traditional cadies made from caramel, coconut and tamarind, among others. She has much experience in this which allows her to make the most delicious candy and earn good profits. She sells both at home and from place to place. She’s acquired a large number of regular customers who prefer her because she always has what they need at affordable prices with good quality products and excellent service. Rosa María is a successful, enterprising woman who is very dedicated to her work. She’s always looking for new opportunities that will lead to success. Demand has increased in recent weeks and she wants to take advantage of this and make a new investment but needs capital to do so which is why she’s asking INTEGRAL for a loan to buy milk, coconut, tamarind, etc. Rosa María has good payment references and assures that she will be able to repay the loan while being confident that she’ll give her family better quality of life. You can see Rosa María 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481934?_te=rlnol.

column2: Maria Eugenia  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Maria Eugenia has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: María Eugenia is a married, 32-year-old mother of a 14-year-old boy. She originates from the Nagarote municipality, which is located in the occidental area of the country. A highlight of Nagarote is that it was declared the cleanest municipality at the department level. It’s also famous for its local food, like “quesillo” (cheese tortillas), tiste (cocoa and corn drink) and crafts. María Eugenia sells quesillos, which are some of the typical foods of this area and are made from tortillas, onions, cream and chillies. The routine of this hard-working woman is to get up every day and go out and sell these quesillos by foot, with about 40kg of weight on her head, under the hot sun. This has been her daily life to raise her son and help with the household expenses. María Eugenia is requesting a loan in order to have business capital and to buy the ingredients for her quesillos, like tortillas, onions, cream, chilli, cheese. She is grateful for the help the Kiva investors give those with limited recourses and poor countries like Nicaragua in order to have sources of dignified work. You can see Maria Eugenia 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481894?_te=rlnol.

column2: Ruth Fonseca  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Ruth Fonseca has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: The Metalworkers Group is made up of three small business owners who are active and entrepreneurial with their businesses, like Ms. Ruth, age 37. She makes skillets and pans of all sizes and types and also sells men's, women's and children's clothing. She also buys and sells crops of tamarind. She is married with two children, who along with her husband help her run the business. She also has workers, which provides employment to heads of households. She will use this loan to purchase materials like aluminum, clothing, and tamarind. María and Carmen also make skillets and pans, while Eugenia Yamileth buys and sells tamarind. You can see Ruth Fonseca 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481908?_te=rlnol.

column2: Ena is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Ena has another loan posted on Kiva! She's been at this work for two years, making her sales on foot around the Mercado Oriental. Before this, she was a homemaker. She will invest this new loan in buying bundles of used clothing, which will offer more variety to her customers. The other members are Rafaela Argentina, who has been selling shoes for 10 years, and Martin José, who has been selling clothing on credit for 18 years. You can see Ena's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481909?_te=rlnol.

column2: Luis Fernando is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3:
We wanted to let you know that Luis Fernando has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Luis worked at a shoe factory for many years, but he lost his job after the owner of the company decided to move the business to another city. It was at that point that he decided to use some of his savings to start his own shoe repair business. At first it was extremely difficult given that he had limited available capital, but gradually he improved his business and his shop has been in operation for 25 years.

Luis is the head of his family, so his wife and three children are dependent on the income generated from his business. For this reason, Luis is always looking each day for ways to improve his business and increase his income. The season is approaching when his sales increase considerably, so Luis is requesting a loan to buy supplies such as soles, rubber, fabric, and other supplies so that he will have sufficient inventory to respond to the requests of his customers.

His dream is to continue his business and improve each day so that his family will have more income and the opportunity to enjoy a better quality of life. He also wants to have more financial opportunities to make progress. You can see Luis Fernando's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481884?_te=rlnol.

column2: Mohamad  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Mohamad has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Mohamad is a 56-year-old married man and father of four children. Mohamad has been manufacturing aluminum closets, doors, and windows since seven years ago. He is an expert in his domain. Mohamad is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua. He will use the loan to buy at wholesale prices necessary merchandise for his business such as the needed accessories for this business and extra aluminum. This will help him increase his net profit, and at the same time work on decreasing his requested prices to please his customers more. This is Mohamad's third borrowing cycle with Al Majmoua. His previous loan was very effective. He bought the requested aluminum compressor, which improves his quality of produced items. Mohamad wants to provide a better lifestyle for his family and expand his business more and more in the future. You can see Mohamad 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480755?_te=rlnol.

column2: Elich \t\t is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Elich has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Elich works sewing dresses for dolls along with his wife Patricia. They have three children, two boys and one girl. Only one of them is school aged. Elich and his family live in the area of Kupini, which is also where their shop is located. This time he is requesting a loan to purchase fabric to make clothing for dolls. Things went very well for him with the previous loan, which is why he is requesting this loan, since there has been an increase in demand for his products. You can see Elich 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481879?_te=rlnol.

column2: Freddy Daniel is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Freddy Daniel has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Freddy Daniel is 54 years old and married with three adult children, who all live on their own. Freddy is originally from the department of Chinandega, which is located in the western region of the country. Chinandega is known for being a productive commercial area. Freddy's business is a welding shop. He has been in business for 45 years, and has it set up in his home. Freddy works with both regular and occasional customers. His daily routine is getting up early to open the doors to the public eight hours a day for all kinds of welding jobs. He learned the trade when he was very young by working alongside his father, who was also a welder. He was able to set up his own shop thanks to his effort and eagerness to work so that he could have the means to support his family, even though currently he has a lighter load to carry since all of his children are working. He needs this financing to invest in his business and purchase a welder so that he can offer his customers better service. Freddy has worked with Fundación León 2000 in the past and has proven himself to be a responsible person and a reliable borrower. He appreciates the help that Kiva investors offer people with limited resources in poor countries like Nicaragua so that they can earn a decent living. You can see Freddy Daniel's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481234?_te=rlnol.

column2: Yely\t\t\t\t is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Yely has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Yely still works at her Internet station and small bookstore. She continues to rent out sound equipment but this time she is requesting a loan for her Internet business. You can see Yely 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481878?_te=rlnol.

column2: Thanks to lenders-for supporting my business

Efua owns a chop bar(small restaurant)where she sells traditional dishes such as fufu and banku.Fufu is made by pounding boiled cassava and plantains into a ball with a large wooden stick in a wooden mortar.It is served with various different meats (Goat, fish, chicken) and soups (Light/tomato, ground nut, palm fruit). Banku is prepared by brining cassava flour, corn flour and water to boil, and mixing them until it is a doughy consistency. Banku is rolled into balls and served with stews, a popular one being okra stew.

\r\n

Efua used her loan to buy more ingredients for her dishes – cassava, plantain, tomatoes, fish, and other meats.She now makes more soup and her sales have increased. Her customers' favourite food is fufu with light soup (tomato-based soup).She uses her profits to re-pay her loan and re-invest in her business. She has not faced any challenges in her business and she has been very happy with her loan.Efua is proud of herself for operating her business successfully and supporting her family. Her dream is to be able to provide a higher education for her children. She thanks lenders for their support.

Using the capital from her loan, Agnes bought ingredients for pastries such as flour, oil, and sugar.She buys these ingredients from cape coast once every two weeks.Cape Coast is the largest town close to her village.

\r\n

She is proud to be able to operate her business on her own.She is now selling a lot more than she was able to before.Her dream is to build a house for her family.She uses the profits from her business to save for cement to build this house.In Ghanaian villages, most houses are built with clay. column2: Natalya is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Natalya has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Natalya lives and works in Novaya Kahovka. Currently, she does not have her own retail space. She leases land from the shopping center administration. Natalya requested an additional financial help in the amount of 10,000 hryvnia because she planned to purchase women's autumn-winter clothing for resale and primarily wants to purchase pants, jackets, skirts, sweaters and cardigans for the cold season. You can see Natalya's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481733?_te=rlnol.

column2: Victoria is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Victoria has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Victoria has used Kiva services several times already. Thanks to the timely obtained financial help, her business not only stayed afloat, but gradually developed and grew. She moved to a new retail location at the same market, where she previously worked. Now, her sales have increased more. This time, Victoria requested a loan in the amount of 10,000 hryvnia to purchase puffer jackets for sale during the cold autumn-winter period. Thanks to the fact that she will increase her goods turnover, she would have to travel less for wholesale merchandise purchases, which would also decrease her expenses and wasted time. Victoria is thinking about developing a website and starting to sell her merchandise also through the Internet, which today is becoming more popular in Ukraine. You can see Victoria's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481730?_te=rlnol.

column2: Beatrice is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Beatrice has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Beatrice is applying for her third loan with KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. Beatrice will use the loan to buy textile materials, thus offering a variety for her customers to choose from. With the anticipated profits from the business, she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to open a boutique which will help her improve the living standards of her family. You can see Beatrice's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480593?_te=rlnol.

column2: Amarjargal is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Amarjargal has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Amarjargal is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two children, ages 6 and 2 years. They live in their own wooden house in Kherlen, the largest city of eastern province of Mongolia. Amarjargal has worked as a court comptroller since 2004 beside his taxi business. His wife, Altansuvd, 29, has been working at a local secondary school as a teacher. In 2006, they got married and built their current house. In that moment, as new couples, expecting a baby, they had a problem with money. So Amarjargal decided to use cheap materials to complete his house. As he planned, they completed their house, but house gets colder than others. As Amarjargal said, it is obvious when weather gets colder, especially in winter; the hoarfrost forms on the surface of the walls. So they need to use more coal to stay warm. This is why Mongolia is one of the worst countries for air pollution. Amarjargal is requesting MNT 3,000,000 to insulate the walls and roof. By doing this, his house will be warm and comfortable and they will burn less coal than usual. You can see Amarjargal's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/479589?_te=rlnol.

column2: Erika is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Erika has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Erika is seeking a new loan in the amount of 10,000 Ukrainian Hryvnia in order to change and diversify her inventory for the autumn-winter season, specifically by buying women's sweaters, blouses and skirts. Erika hopes that the Kiva loan will allow her to increase her gross revenue and her profit. You can see Erika's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481728?_te=rlnol.

column2: Visitando a la socia Carmen, ejemplo de trabajo de su grupo "ATIPAY GROUP"
column3: La socia es la señora Carmen, ella pertenece al banco comunal "ATIPAY GROUP" de la ciudad del Cusco, Perú. La socia es un ejemplo de trabajo y perseverancia de su grupo al que pertenece, pues su actividad comercial al igual que muchos de sus compañeros de grupo, es la comercialización de calzados para damas, caballeros y niños, trabajo que viene realizando hace algunos años y que le ha permitido sacar adelante a su familia. Carmen invirtió su último préstamo para comprar Mercadería como zapatos, zapatillas, botas, etc. para cumplir con las solicitudes de su clientela. Carmen comenta muy orgullosa, que está satisfecha y agradecida por la oportunidad que KIVA le ofrece, por invertir en el mantenimiento de su actividad económica y por permitirle ofrecer mejor calidad de vida a su familia.

El socio es el Señor Werner, él pertenece al banco comunal "Señor de Huanca de Cusco Group" de la ciudad del Cusco, Perú. Werner sigue dedicándose a su actividad de la carpintería, principalmente en la elaboración de muebles para el hogar, y con su trabajo ha podido mejorar la calidad de vida de toda su familia, ya que todos sus miembros participan activamente en esta actividad, y precisamente para ello es que Werner invirtió su último préstamo, él compró material de trabajo como madera, tornillos, y accesorios para sus herramientas que le permitan continuar con la producción de sus muebles.

\r\n

Werner está muy agradecido con KIVA que le permite mantenerse y crecer en su actividad comercial por ayudarlo a ofrecerle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.

column2: Rama is taking out another loan on Kiva

column2: Lilit is taking out another loan on Kiva

In the future, Lilit intends to develop her business and to relocate her business from her apartment to the workshop. You can see Lilit's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480366?_te=rlnol.

column2: Flood in Georgia damaged Zaur's business

column2: Marta Daisy is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Marta Daisy has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Marta Daisy 2012-280 800.000 Marta, 59, is a very responsible, hard-working woman who is requesting a third loan through the foundation to expand her business. She will invest in catalogue products and supplies to make bed linens, thanks to a course she took at INA. Her daughter and granddaughter will help with sales and she plans to improve the quality of the products she sews, with the sewing machines she will buy. She has an excellent credit record and is very dedicated to the work she does. She also works as a baby-sitter for two children, demonstrating her desire to work and improve her quality of life. She lives with her daughter, granddaughter and husband in Aserri, where her husband's family lives. Fundación Mujer is the institution that supported Marta with an initial loan of 250,000 CRC for sales. She then moved to Aserri and, together with her husband, started a business with 40 small egg-laying hens The loan for this has been paid off. Due to health issues her husband had to quit the chicken business and return to San Rafael de Alajuela in his previous job. She wants to take advantage of her sewing experience to make bedspreads and other bed linens. Marta has the capacity to take on the debt and has demonstrated excellent payment conduct with previous loans. And, she will diversify her products for the fixed customer base she already has. Her granddaughter and daughter will also help out with sales. To her fixed clientele she shows fashion catalogues, and renews her merchandise when necessary. She has studied courses at INA and wants to use her expertise making bed linens and bedspreads. She needs two sewing machines to give her products a better finish. For now she is using a machine she borrowed from her granddaughter. This is her third loan. She also takes care of children in the morning and afternoon. On weekends she dedicates time to her business and works from home, since this is the best option for earning an income for her family. You can see Marta Daisy's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481249?_te=rlnol.

column2: Maribel  is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Maribel has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: The San José community bank has nine members who are all women aged between 30 and 60. They have 15 children in their care and live in the town of El Sauce, in the north of the country. El Sauce is known for its milk, curds and cream production, for its corn growing and for its pig raising. All the members of this group are hard-working and responsible people. Maribel is the coordinator of the community bank. She is responsible for ensuring that every member makes her payments on time and in full. Maribel's business is selling 'cosa de horno' which is a traditional cake made from corn, curds and cinnamon. Maribel's routine involves getting up at 4.00am to make her 'cosa de horno'. She then goes out to make her sales as an itinerant street vendor. She works until 4.00pm, carrying her products in a basket on her head under the intense daily sun. The San José community bank are grateful for the help that Kiva investors provide to people with limited resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua. It enables them to make a decent living. You can see Maribel 's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481264?_te=rlnol.

column2: cập nhập thông tin nhóm 06.07.01 Đông Vệ
column3:
Chị Bùi Thị Xuân 50 tuổi là nhóm trưởng nhóm 01 Quảng Xá3 - Phường Đông Vệ - Tp Thanh Hóa. Tước đây chị chủ yếu ở nhà lo nội trợ, từ khi có chương trình vay vốn của Quỹ hỗ trợ phụ nữ nghèo chị đã làm đơn xin vay vốn – hiện tại chị đang vay mức 5.310.000VNĐ(~252.85USD) – thời hạn vay 12 tháng, chị đầu tư vào nấu rượu nhờ chịu thương chịu khó mà trung bình một ngày chị cũng thu được 100.000VNĐ(~4.8USD), với mức thu nhập như vậy chị có thể góp thêm vào trang trải cho cuộc sống và lo cho các con ăn học. Chị cảm thấy phấn khởi và cảm ơn Quỹ đã tạo điều kiện cho chị vay vốn, chị mong muốn sẽ được vay cao hơn trong các chu kỳ tiếp theo để đầu tư và mở rộng thêm công việc kinh doanh của mình.

Chị Hợp vay vốn để mua thêm hạt giống ,phân bón và các dụng cụ về phục vụ cho nông nghiệp, nhờ đảm đang và tháo vát hàng ngày chị cần mẫn hái rau đi bán trung bình một ngày chị bán được 50.000VNĐ(~2.3USD) với mức thu nhập như vậy cuộc sống của chị giờ đã vất vã hơn trước.

Chị Hồng vay vốn của Quỹ để chăn nuôi, chị mua 10 con lợn giống hết gần 3.000.000 VNĐ (~142,8USD). Hàng ngày chị đi lấy nước gạo ở khu phố chị sinh sống và tận dụng rau ở ngoài vườn để nuôi lợn.Chị dự tính sau 6 tháng chăn nuôi trừ đi chi phí các chị thu được lợi nhuận là 15.000.000VNĐ(~750USD).Với mức thu nhập như vậy gia đình chị có cuộc sống tương đối ổn định.

Chị Hạnh vay vốn của Quỹ để bán hàng giải khát.Hàng ngày trung bình chị thu nhập được 100.000VNĐ(~4.76USD) đủ để trang trải cuộc sống và lo cho các con ăn học.

Ama is married to a farmer and has two children.She lives with her family in a village called eguafo, located in the elmina district Ghana.Ama took out kiva loan from field partner, cran microfinance because she had no working capital. She used to buy her items on credit.She prepares and sells banku. Banku is a Ghanaian staple made from fermented cassava and maize dough. It is usually served with fried fish and hot pepper sauce and also soup and stew.She serves banku with palm nut soup.She sells banku every afternoon except on weekends.She admits that that the loan has been helping her business and family,this is because she can now support her husband to take care of the children's school fees. She mainly reinvests her profit. She is grateful to kiva lenders.

Auntie operates a provision store.She sells different kinds of items like cooking oil, vegetables, raw eggs, rice, beans, etc.She stays at mpoho, takoradi, in the western region.She took out the loan because she wanted to give her business a facelift. Her shop fell apart so she was compelled to arrange her wares on a table. After taking out the loan, she used part of the amount to renovate her shop and used the rest to buy more stuff. Her business is doing well, thanks to kiva lenders.

\r\n

She plans to buy a car and rent it out as taxi.She would like to use the income from the taxi business for her children's education.She is grateful to kiva lenders and she hopes and prays that they would continue to support her small business.

He is thankful and really works hard to further improve his income in doing well his business. He is hoping that lenders will always support him.

column2: Jovelyn is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Jovelyn has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: This is Jovelyn. She previously accessed an 18,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, house hold and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another 22,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. Jovelyn dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes for a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans. You can see Jovelyn's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/528650?_te=rlnol.

Tea received the Kiva loan in January of the current year. She used it for predetermined purposes. Tea purchased calves and keeps them i the shed located in her yard. She raises them and plans to sell after several months.

\n\n

Tea is thankful to all Kiva lenders who raised her loan on the web-site.

Evangeline is so much thankful to ASKI and KIVA lenders because they gave her chance to borrow loan that she invests in her business improvement. She bought various groceries and added product offerings to retail. She is happy that now, her sales is increasing. She hope to continue make improvement in the business to give her daughter a bright future despite being a single mother.

Thelma is thankful to KIVA lenders through ASKI for their financial assistance in her business. When she got her loan, she bought vegetables, pork meat, and fish to sell in their village. According to Thelma, her borrowed loan helps a lot in her business because she gains more income with this. She hopes that it will further grow for her family.

Greetings from Armenia!

\r\n

column2: Cap nhat thong tin nhom vay 06.02.01 Đông Vệ
column3:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Ngân là trưởng nhóm 01 Mật Sơn 1- Phường Đông Vệ. Gia đình chị có nghề làm hàng mã từ xưa, chị muốn mở rộng thêm ngành nghề nhưng gia đình chị không có đủ vốn. Nhờ có Quỹ Hỗ Trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo chị đã làm đơn xin vay vốn, chị được vay mức: 5.310.000VNĐ (~252.85USD) Chị đầu tư vào để mua nguyên vật liệu và thuê thêm 2 nhân công về làm cùng gia đình. Nhờ nhanh nhẹn, tháo vát và khéo tay mà công việc của chị ngày một thuận lợi hơn, gia đình chị có nhiều người đến đặt mua hàng. Hàng ngày tuy bận rộn vất vã nhưng chị thấy phấn khởi vì có thêm nguồn thu nhập cho gia đình.Trừ đi chi phí và tiền thuê nhân công một ngày chị cũng kiếm được 130.000VNĐ (~6.19USD), có tiền để lo cho con ăn học và trang trải cuộc sống, ngoài ra chị còn tiết kiệm được một khoản đề lo cho tương lai của các con. Chị cảm ơn Quỹ đã tạo điều kiện cho chị vay vốn.

Chị Ý vay vốn của Quỹ để đầu tư bán hàng ăn. Hàng ngày trung bình chị thu nhập được 120.000VND (~5.7USD) đủ để nuôi con ăn học và trang trải cuộc sống hàng ngày.

Chị Hoa vay vốn để mua thêm con giống về chăn nuôi. Hàng ngày chị đi lấy nước rác từ các nhà trong xóm và tận dụng rau trong vườn để chăn nuôi. Sau tháng trừ đi chi phí gia đình chị cũng thu nhập được 10.000.000VNĐ(~476.19USD) cuộc sống của gia đình chị đã ổn định hơn trước.

Chị Lý vay vốn để bán măng. Hàng ngày chị bán lẻ ở chợ tuy vất vả nhưng trung bình một ngày chị thu nhập được 100.000VNĐ (~4.76USD) ngoài lo toan ăn uống hàng ngày chị còn tiết kiệm được một khoản để lo cho con ăn học.

Chị Bé vay vốn để mua thêm nguyên vật liệu về làm nghề hàng mã. Trung bình một ngày chị thu nhập được 100.000VNĐ(~4.76USD) góp thêm phần thu nhập để phụ giúp cho gia đình.

Greetings from Armenia!

\r\n

Thank you for supporting Karine to develop her business. With the loan's help Karine has purchased women's jeans clothing, which is highly demanded in the market. Karine started gathering more business income, which allowed her to pay off the loan successfully and keep investing in her business.

\r\n

Karine thanks all her borrowers for this opportunity.

Lucia is a very industrious woman. Despite her age, she was known to be a very business minded person. The loan she borrowed from ASKI and KIVA lenders was carefully budget in purchasing variety of fish such as milkfish, tilapia and other variety to sell. She was very glad for the support of the lenders and hoping for her business to become more profitable.

Julie is engaged in food selling business, particularly in buying and selling fish. Having additional capital from KIVA lenders and ASKI made her maintain the business. She bought different kinds of fish such as milk fish and "tilapia" to sell. She hopes that she can have a good profit for her to provide the needs of her family. She was very thankful to all the lenders for supporting her micro enterprise.

column2: Robert is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Robert has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Robert used the previous loan to buy fish to sell. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after the family, and his dream is to have a sustainable income-generating activity to support his family. Robert is a fish vendor and has been in this business for 11 years now. His major challenge is the high license fees, and his dream is to buy a refrigerating van. With the income earned he has been able to pay school fees for his children and set up a business for his wife. Robert intends to use the loan to buy fish to sell. You can see Robert's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/479804?_te=rlnol.

Femer is extending her gratitude to KIVA lenders and ASKI for believing and trusting her in making her business grow.

The loan was utilized in purchasing agricultural inputs he needed for the maintenance of his farm. He is grateful that he also gain higher profits that he use to maintain their household needs, especially the needs of his children in school. Aurelio hopes to see his children finish their college education someday.

She is thankful for the financial support received, it greatly contributed to her business simple growth where her family is benefiting much on it.

He is thankful that through the business, he could get bigger income now for his family and education of his one child. His hope is to get loan again the second time around after paying this current loan soon.

column2: Jane is taking out another loan on Kiva

column2: Mercedes Del Socorro is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Mercedes Del Socorro has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Mercedes del Socorro is 45 years old, married and has two children who are 24 and 26 years old and economically independent. She is from the city of Chinandega. She sells merchandise, generally new and used, and recycled material like clothes and shoes. She has an experience of 15 years in which she proved to be a good payer in a timely manner. She distributes the merchandise as a street peddler to permanent and temporary clients. Mercedes’ daily routine is 10 hours a day, from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm. She started the business as a way to survive because at that moment her husband and her didn’t have a job. Today, the business is profitable because it helps to cover many of the household expenses. Also, the family burden is lighter because their children work. She is grateful for the help provided by Kiva lenders to people with limited resources and to poor countries like Nicaragua so they can have a decent way to work. You can see Mercedes Del Socorro's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/481235?_te=rlnol.

column2: Agnes is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Agnes has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: Agnes has been running a green grocer business in an open air market for the past seven years. Her monthly income has increased and this has enabled her to provide the basic needs for her family. Her profit is KES. 15,000. Here's the description of their new loan: She’s a member of the “María Auxiliadora” communal bank and continues with her business selling dry grains. She’s been in this business for years and does well thanks to the effort she puts into her business every day. She buys potato and quinoa seeds, among others, to sell in her locale. She has a store where she sells all the merchandise her customers request from her. She’s a responsible, dedicated person who moves forward this way. She’s requesting the loan to buy potato and quinoa seeds for her business. She feels grateful for the granted loan and commits to make her installment payments as scheduled. You can see Yaneth's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480883?_te=rlnol.

column2: Elsa is taking out another loan on Kiva
column3: We wanted to let you know that Elsa has another loan posted on Kiva! Here's the description of their new loan: This is Elsa. She previously accessed a 14,000 PHP loan that she used to buy additional stock of decorative plastic flowers and plants. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan for her to again buy additional stock of decorative plastic flower and plants. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her sustain her daily needs and pay the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. Elsa hopes to expand soon. She dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She also dreams of having her own house and lot someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. At these meetings, she can also draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. * All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay back microfinance loans. You can see Elsa's new loan by visiting http://www.kiva.org/lend/480078?_te=rlnol.
